Film Reviews

Review: A Hijacking

By James Bithell

Hollywood should take note from this tense and gritty thriller. Tom Lubek reviews.

Review: The Great Gatsby

By James Bithell

Any joys to be found in Baz Luhrmann's adaptation of F. Scott Fitzgerald's classic novel are entirely superficial.

Review: Star Trek Into Darkness

By James Bithell

J.J Abrams second instalment of this rebooted franchise manages to deftly balance intense action with intelligent character development.

Review: Iron Man 3

It may upset the fan-boys, but comic moments rather than comic books are at the heart of Marvel's latest crowd-pleaser. Alfie Packham reviews.

Review: The Place Beyond The Pines

By James Bithell

Derek Cianfrance's latest explores themes of fatherhood and legacy and is bolstered by unparalleled performances from Ryan Gosling and Bradley Cooper

Review: A Late Quartet

By James Bithell

Distinguished actors redeem this heroic story of an ageing quartet's end-game

Review: The Host

By James Bithell

An awkward adaptation for newcomers to Meyer, despite an eye-catching sci-fi sheen. Katrina Northern reviews.

Review: In the House

By James Bithell

The viewer is irresistibly drawn into Claude and Germain's literary game

Review: Trance

By James Bithell

Barbed with graphic visuals and a sharp plot that should be a conversation starter.

Human Rights Watch Festival 2013: Camp 14

By James Bithell

The Human Rights Watch Festival brings Camp 14: Total Control Zone, recalling the struggles of Shin Dong-hyuk in the North Korean prison camp he was born in.

Human Rights Watch Festival 2013: My Afghanistan

By James Bithell

Part of the Human Rights Watch Film Festival, My Afghanistan - Life in the Forbidden Zone uses civilian footage to sensitively expose the realities of Afghan life in Helmand Province

Review: Broken City

By James Bithell

Despite a star-studded cast, Broken City suffers from a tired, predictable plot.

Review: Safe Haven

By James Bithell

Sloppy, fairly soppy, and compares poorly to previous Sparks adaptations

Review: Mama

By James Bithell

Mama bears Del Toro's imprint and will scare its audience, when they're not laughing.

Review: Side Effects

By James Bithell

This clinically cool pyscho-thriller loses a star for relapsing into a conventional narrative. Tom Lubek reviews

Review: Oz the Great and Powerful

By James Bithell

With Oz transformed and its wizard well cast, Disney invokes more than nostalgia. Ruth Bury reviews

Review: Stoker

By James Bithell

Joseph Harrison finds that Chan-wook Park's latest is a uniquely stylised and gloriously sinister modern gothic thriller

Review: Cloud Atlas

By James Bithell

Despite its poignant moments, Cloud Atlas is an epic blighted by absurdity. Alfie Packham reviews

Review: Song For Marion

By James Bithell

Joseph Harrison find that Song For Marion is saved by some fine central performances from Vanessa Redgrave and Terrence Stamp

Review: A Good Day to Die Hard

By James Bithell

It would be a good day to call the food standards agency, because this dead horse has been flogged enough times to pass as beef. Alfie Packham reviews.

Review: Warm Bodies

By James Bithell

Warm Bodies, a self-proclaimed Rom-Zom-Com, suffers from a bland script that is more suited to a high school drama than a zombie film. Joseph Harrison reviews.

Review: I Give It A Year

By James Bithell

I Give It A Year, the directorial debut from long-time Sacha Baron-Cohen collaborator, offers lots of laughs but isn't entirely original.

Review: Hitchcock

By James Bithell

Hitchcock has pulled in followers of the famed director of Psycho. However, this muddled film was apparently overwhelmed by the man's enigmatic aura. Steven Roberts reviews.

Review: The Impossible

By James Bithell

In his portrayal of the deadly Boxing Day tsunami, Bayona confidently engages with sensitive subject matter and produces a touching picture. But it is not altogether a humbling one. Steven Roberts reviews.

Review: Lincoln

By James Bithell

Spielberg's long-awaited Abraham Lincoln biopic is elegant powerful and surprisingly relevant making it more than worthy of the considerable awards buzz. Agatha Torrance reviews.

Review: Django Unchained

By James Bithell

Although Django Unchained is unquestionably entertaining and possesses all the expected traits we have come to expect from a Tarantino film, he could perhaps gain from returning to the real world. Harry Lambert reviews

Review: Gangster Squad

By James Bithell

Ruben Fleischer presents The Battle of Los Angeles, with a little help from slow-mo. Alfie Packham reviews.

Review: Les Miserables

By James Bithell

Tom Hooper's screen adaption of the long-running musical is undoubtedly impressive and possesses a stunning central performance from Anne Hathaway, but is let down by its long run time and some dubious vocal performances. Maddy Breen review.

Review: Europe's Last Dictator

By James Bithell

Winner of the award for 'Best Documentary' at the London Independent Film Festival, Europe's Last Dictator is an expose of Alexander Lukashenko's tyrannical reign. Stephen Thorne reviews.

Review: Jack Reacher

By James Bithell

Cruise's glowering Reacher is a hit, but fails to make up for a story line that lacks inventiveness. Rachel Thompson reviews.

Review: A Hijacking

By James Bithell

Hollywood should take note from this tense and gritty thriller. Tom Lubek reviews.
